metadata.source: Paper 13 Section 4.2 — Hierarchical Cross-Domain Reasoning Rules

rules.name: Modus Ponens
rules.description: If P is true and P implies Q, then Q must be true. The fundamental rule of logical deduction.

rules.name: Modus Tollens
rules.description: If Q is false and P implies Q, then P must be false. Denying the consequent.

rules.name: Hypothetical Syllogism
rules.description: If P implies Q and Q implies R, then P implies R. Chaining conditional statements.

rules.name: Disjunctive Syllogism
rules.description: If either P or Q is true and P is false, then Q must be true. Elimination by disjunction.

rules.name: Constructive Dilemma
rules.description: Given two conditionals and a disjunction of their antecedents, conclude a disjunction of their consequents.

rules.name: Reductio ad Absurdum
rules.description: If assuming P leads to a contradiction, then P must be false. Proof by contradiction.

rules.name: Universal Instantiation
rules.description: If a property holds for all elements, it holds for any specific element. From universal to particular.

rules.name: Existential Generalization
rules.description: If a property holds for a specific element, then there exists some element with that property.

rules.name: De Morgan's Laws
rules.description: The negation of a conjunction is the disjunction of negations, and vice versa.

rules.name: Contraposition
rules.description: A conditional and its contrapositive are logically equivalent. If not Q then not P.

rules.name: Transitivity
rules.description: If a relation holds from A to B and from B to C, it holds from A to C. Chaining ordered relations.

rules.name: Law of Excluded Middle
rules.description: Every proposition is either true or its negation is true. No middle ground exists.

rules.name: Double Negation
rules.description: The negation of a negation returns the original proposition.

rules.name: Material Implication
rules.description: An implication can be rewritten as the disjunction of the negated antecedent with the consequent.

rules.name: Biconditional
rules.description: A biconditional holds if and only if both directions of implication hold simultaneously.

rules.name: Newton's Second Law
rules.formal_statement: F = ma (net force equals mass times acceleration)
rules.description: The net force on an object equals its mass times its acceleration. Force causes acceleration proportional to mass.

rules.name: Conservation of Energy
rules.description: Total energy in an isolated system remains constant. Energy transforms between forms but is never created or destroyed.

rules.name: Conservation of Momentum
rules.description: Total momentum before and after a collision or interaction remains the same in an isolated system.

rules.name: Newton's Third Law
rules.description: For every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force. Forces always come in pairs.

rules.name: Ohm's Law
rules.formal_statement: V = IR (voltage equals current times resistance)
rules.description: Voltage across a conductor equals the current flowing through it times its resistance.

rules.name: Ideal Gas Law
rules.description: For an ideal gas, the product of pressure and volume equals the amount of gas times the gas constant times temperature.

rules.name: Archimedes' Principle
rules.description: The buoyant force on a submerged object equals the weight of the fluid it displaces.

rules.name: Hooke's Law
rules.description: The force exerted by a spring is proportional to its displacement from equilibrium and opposes the displacement.

rules.name: Coulomb's Law
rules.description: The electrostatic force between two charges is proportional to their product and inversely proportional to the square of the distance.

rules.name: First Law of Thermodynamics
rules.formal_statement: ΔU = Q - W (internal energy change equals heat minus work)
rules.description: The change in internal energy of a system equals heat added minus work done by the system. Energy conservation for thermodynamic systems.

rules.name: Second Law of Thermodynamics
rules.description: The total entropy of an isolated system always increases or stays the same. Natural processes tend toward maximum disorder.

rules.name: Bernoulli's Equation
rules.formal_statement: P + ½ρv² + ρgh = constant along a streamline
rules.description: For steady, incompressible flow, the sum of pressure, kinetic, and potential energy per unit volume is constant along a streamline.

rules.name: Distributive Property
rules.description: Multiplication distributes over addition. A factor applied to a sum equals the sum of the factor applied to each term.

rules.name: Associative Property
rules.description: Grouping of operations does not affect the result. Parentheses can be rearranged for addition and multiplication.

rules.name: Commutative Property
rules.description: The order of operands does not affect the result for addition and multiplication.

rules.name: Proportion and Ratio
rules.description: Equal ratios imply cross products are equal. Used to solve for unknowns in proportional relationships.

rules.name: Rate Times Time Equals Quantity
rules.description: Quantity equals rate multiplied by time. Fundamental relationship for speed, work rate, flow, and production problems.

rules.name: Percentage
rules.description: A percentage represents a part of a whole scaled by 100. Used in discounts, taxes, growth rates.

rules.name: Area Formulas
rules.description: Standard formulas for computing area of geometric shapes from their dimensions.

rules.name: Pythagorean Theorem
rules.formal_statement: a² + b² = c² for right triangles
rules.description: In a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

rules.name: Arithmetic Sequences
rules.description: Each term in an arithmetic sequence is obtained by adding a common difference to the previous term.

rules.name: Geometric Sequences
rules.description: Each term in a geometric sequence is obtained by multiplying the previous term by a common ratio.

rules.name: Combinatorics
rules.description: The number of ways to choose r items from n without regard to order. Combinations formula.

rules.name: Modular Arithmetic
rules.formal_statement: a ≡ b (mod n) iff n divides (a-b)
rules.description: Two numbers are congruent modulo n if they have the same remainder when divided by n.

rules.name: Supply and Demand
rules.formal_statement: Price adjusts until quantity supplied equals quantity demanded (equilibrium)
rules.description: Market price is determined by the intersection of supply and demand curves. Excess supply lowers prices; excess demand raises them.

rules.name: Opportunity Cost
rules.description: The true cost of choosing an option is the value of the best alternative you give up.

rules.name: Diminishing Returns
rules.description: Each additional unit of input produces progressively less additional output beyond some point.

rules.name: Comparative Advantage
rules.formal_statement: Trade when relative opportunity costs differ between parties
rules.description: Parties benefit from trade when they specialize in producing goods for which they have the lowest opportunity cost.

rules.name: Compound Interest
rules.description: Future value equals principal times one plus rate raised to the number of periods. Interest earns interest.

rules.name: Accounting Equation
rules.description: Total assets must always equal total liabilities plus equity. The fundamental balance sheet identity.

rules.name: Break-Even Analysis
rules.description: The break-even point is where total revenue exactly equals total costs. No profit, no loss.

rules.name: Elasticity
rules.description: Price elasticity measures how responsive quantity demanded or supplied is to a change in price.

rules.name: Marginal Cost Equals Marginal Benefit
rules.description: The optimal level of an activity is where the additional cost equals the additional benefit.

rules.name: Nash Equilibrium
rules.formal_statement: No player gains from unilateral deviation
rules.description: A stable state where no player can improve their outcome by changing only their own strategy.

rules.name: Bayes' Rule
rules.description: Updates the probability of a hypothesis given new evidence. Posterior is proportional to likelihood times prior.

rules.name: Law of Total Probability
rules.description: The probability of an event equals the sum of its conditional probabilities weighted by the partition probabilities.

rules.name: Independence
rules.formal_statement: P(A∩B) = P(A)P(B) iff A and B are independent
rules.description: Two events are independent if and only if their joint probability equals the product of their individual probabilities.

rules.name: Conditional Probability
rules.description: The probability of A given B is the probability of both occurring divided by the probability of B.

rules.name: Simpson's Paradox
rules.formal_statement: A trend in subgroups can reverse when groups are combined
rules.description: A statistical trend that appears in several groups can reverse when the groups are combined, due to a confounding variable.

rules.name: Regression to the Mean
rules.formal_statement: Extreme observations tend toward the average on retest
rules.description: Unusually high or low values are likely to be followed by values closer to the average due to random variation.

rules.name: Base Rate Neglect
rules.formal_statement: P(H|E) depends on P(H) not just P(E|H)
rules.description: Judgments should account for the base rate (prior probability) of a hypothesis, not just the likelihood of the evidence.

rules.name: Correlation Does Not Imply Causation
rules.description: A statistical correlation between two variables does not prove that one causes the other. Confounders or reverse causation may exist.

rules.name: Sampling Bias
rules.description: Conclusions drawn from a non-representative sample may not generalize to the full population.

rules.name: Central Limit Theorem
rules.formal_statement: Sample means → Normal distribution as n→∞
rules.description: The distribution of sample means approaches a normal distribution as sample size increases, regardless of the population distribution.

rules.name: Natural Selection
rules.formal_statement: Heritable traits that increase fitness spread in populations
rules.description: Organisms with traits better suited to their environment reproduce more, causing those traits to become more common over generations.

rules.name: Homeostasis
rules.formal_statement: Biological systems maintain internal equilibrium via feedback loops
rules.description: Living organisms regulate internal conditions like temperature, pH, and glucose to maintain a stable internal environment.

rules.name: Dose-Response Relationship
rules.description: The magnitude of a biological response is related to the amount of exposure or dosage of a substance.

rules.name: Mendelian Inheritance
rules.formal_statement: Phenotype determined by genotype combinations (dominant/recessive alleles)
rules.description: Traits are inherited through discrete units (genes) that combine according to predictable rules of dominance and segregation.

rules.name: Differential Diagnosis
rules.formal_statement: Observed symptoms → ranked list of candidate causes
rules.description: Given a set of symptoms, systematically narrow down possible diseases or conditions by comparing against known patterns.

rules.name: Triage
rules.formal_statement: Prioritize treatment by severity and likelihood of survival
rules.description: Allocate limited medical resources to patients based on urgency and expected outcome to maximize overall benefit.

rules.name: Epidemiological Spread (R₀)
rules.description: The basic reproduction number measures how many people one infected person will infect on average. R₀ > 1 means epidemic growth.

rules.name: Temporal Ordering
rules.formal_statement: If A occurs before B, A may cause B but B cannot cause A
rules.description: Causes must precede their effects in time. Something that happens later cannot be the cause of something earlier.

rules.name: Spatial Containment
rules.formal_statement: If A is in B, and B is in C, then A is in C (transitivity)
rules.description: Containment is transitive: if something is inside a container that is inside another container, it is also inside the outer container.

rules.name: Object Permanence
rules.formal_statement: Objects continue to exist when not being observed
rules.description: Physical objects persist even when we cannot see or interact with them. Things don't disappear when unobserved.

rules.name: Functional Affordance
rules.formal_statement: Objects have typical uses determined by their properties
rules.description: Objects are typically used for purposes that their physical properties enable. Cups hold liquid, chairs support sitting.

rules.name: Social Reciprocity
rules.formal_statement: Positive actions tend to elicit positive responses, and vice versa
rules.description: People tend to respond to kindness with kindness and hostility with hostility. Social interactions are reciprocal.

rules.name: Planning and Subgoaling
rules.formal_statement: Complex goals are achieved by decomposing into ordered subgoals
rules.description: To accomplish a complex objective, break it into smaller steps and execute them in a logical order.

rules.name: Counterfactual Reasoning
rules.formal_statement: If X had not happened, Y would not have happened
rules.description: Reasoning about what would have been different if a past event had not occurred. Used for causal judgment and blame attribution.

rules.name: Default Reasoning
rules.formal_statement: Assume typical properties unless stated otherwise
rules.description: In the absence of specific information, assume the most common or typical case. Birds can fly unless told otherwise.

rules.name: Numeric Estimation (Fermi)
rules.formal_statement: Estimate by decomposing into tractable sub-estimates and multiplying
rules.description: Estimate unknown quantities by breaking the problem into smaller, estimable parts and combining the estimates.
